text:
Good afternoon everybody. Today, we're going to to do a session
on B2B product with a panel.

Jason Lemkin is going to moderate. Thank you very much. We have Solomon from Docker,
Tracy from Plangrid, and Harry from Lob.

Thank you all very much for coming. >> So, this is a great session, everyone
seen all the prior sessions online, right?

Raise your hand if you haven't. All right, good, 100%. They're great. So I watched Stewart Butterfield and
others.

And what I thought would be particularly
fun since we have three amazing founders here of B2B companies, is to particularly
hone in on the intersection of building

great products and revenue because we
all want to be product visionaries. I certainly did myself.

But if you can't sell it and
it's a B2B product, ultimately, what's the point of all of it. So I want to dig into a couple of stories
both in the early days and a little bit

later to help folks like you who probably
just have inklings on how to potentially

monetize your dreams because the stories
are always different than we think. So let me give 10 seconds
on each of the panelists,

then let me have them dig in a little
bit more on their companies. But Solomon from Docker, I don't know
who here knows about Docker, but

I'm guessing most of the 300,000
folks online that'll read it. But Docker, he'll give you some
more context, founded in 2010,

but not as Docker,
what was it called back then? >> dotCloud. >> dotCloud, which we'll get to a story,

raised almost 200 million,
and Docker is sort of a foundational piece of infrastructure
that everyone builds up around today.

So we'll get into that, but it is
seven years into this journey, right? Into a likely 70 year journey or
14 year journey.

Tracy probably gets probably in
the middle of this rock star group.

Plangrid was found a little bit later. 2011?
>> 2011. >> Got it. Raised 60 million? >> Something like that.

>> Right.
So money isn't everything, but it does help. And Plangrid you'll learn is super cool,
automates construction management and

kind of has shaken up
a shockingly large industry, shockingly large parts of software and

you'll learn a little bit more about
those stories and I want to learn more. And then Harry runs Lob which turns mail

into an API which I think
is pretty interesting. Raised $10 million and so
he's got another $190 million to catch up.

$50 million, but
off to a very strong start. Founded in 2013? >> Yes.

>> What's that? [INAUDIBLE] Yeah, all right, and
in you're four years in, right? So it's just when it's getting both
good and hard, right, at the same time.

I would imagine, right? So I want to begin but those are the
intros, but give me a little bit more

Intro on the company like number of
employees, and what's the latest challenge you have today, or
any other quick tidbits on the company.
>> Sure. So currently it's 350 employees at Docker. We actually started in 2008.

>> 2008?
>> Yeah. We're bootstrapped in France and
then it wasn't working, so we moved here got into YC and
that really, really, really helped.

So anyway. >> Got it.
>> Nine years. >> Nine years.
>> [LAUGH] >> You just sort of refound the company or

do you count those earlier so you-
>> It depends who you ask but yeah. >> [LAUGH]
>> It counts, the same company,

same problem we're trying to solve. So 350 employees, lot's of growth,
lot's of excitement.

The biggest challenge for us, the biggest
challenge last year was proving that we could build a business, a viable hi-growth
business on top of this excitement for

stuff that is in large part free,
in open source. That was last year,
we proved that model and

this year we have
the challenge is to scale it. And to scale it faster than our
competitors who now figured out that

the model is proven. So it's a big competitive battle and
a really lucrative space, so that's the challenge this year.

>> Good.
>> [INAUDIBLE] >> Hi, everyone, my name is Tracy Young. I'm one of the cofounders and CEO of Plangrid. Plangrid builds, as you said, beautiful,
simple, effective software for

the construction industry. We emerged from
Y Combinators Winners 2012 batch.

And since then, we've grown from
five co-founders to 310 people, which is not something to brag about,
it means our payroll is very high.

>> [LAUGH]
>> But we've helped build over 500,000 construction projects from the smallest
kitchen remodels to the largest projects

in the world and
we are available on all the platforms. Apple actually named us one of
the top 10 enterprise apps of 2016,

which is pretty awesome. Now we're also the largest digital
blueprint repository in the world,

we have over 50 million sheets of
blueprints in our cloud and growing.

>> Thanks. So I'm sitting here. We've got 40 employees,
hoping I wish I had 150.

>> [LAUGH]
>> But a little bit about Lob, I'm one of the founders. My name's Harry Zhang.

Started company in 2013, and what we
do is build tools and make it easy for developers to control the offline world.

So we actually deal with a physical
component, an industry that many of you think may be dying, but in fact,
it is very much the opposite.

Doing letters, postcards and
other types of mails and really building a layer of technology on top of that to
make it easy for companies to do that.

So hopefully, many of you have
received a piece of mail from Lob, especially in this area and
the Bay Area and we service companies.

We're trying to make this switch into
selling to mid-market, and other startups, and to selling it to the Fortune 500.

So a lot of our challenges today is
really how do we move into Enterprise and take what used to be
a lone single tool and

translate it into a larger full
solution for larger companies. >> Good, so hang onto the microphone
because there's just one other question I

want to ask the whole panel. But I really like to talk about the
concept of a minimum sale-able product,

not a viable product, like what it
actually takes to make real money. So Harry, tell me what happened with Lob,

do not count other companies from
your batch, or customers [INAUDIBLE]. How did you get those first
[INAUDIBLE] customers and

what made the product sale-able? >> Sure, yeah, I think one of the common
things that's easy to get in the habit of

thinking that customers are going to come
to you because you have a great product, have a great solution. That works maybe in the beginning for
smaller companies, but

as you go after your first real customer, our first real customer was
Oscar Insurance over in New York.

So the way we got to
them was cold email and we sent thousands and thousands of emails.

I personally wrote every single one and
got a response from the CEO.

And I think one of the key
things is to really have an understanding of why
are companies going to talk to you?

What is the problem you might be solving
for them as supposed to like here is what my product does and
these are the features that I have, right?

You want to be very pinpoint
about what the message is. People are actually surprisingly open
to respond your email as long as it's

relevant. So for us, we happened to hit
on the problem for Oscar, which is they had a mail vendor and
they knew there was this regulation called

HIPPA which is essentially how you govern
and control private health information.

And what we realized was that
this was our opportunity and they're looking at new vendors. They did not trust their existing
vendor had HIPAA and was secure.

And we could point to a small
customer we had already done it for in the past and
that's how we got into the conversation.

Took us about two or three months to get
the deal done, but really what you need is to identify a core problem that larger
companies haven't quite figured out and

even if your solution isn't
the best that's out there, it needs to be to a point where
the customers are willing to buy.

So we started off with one use case. Very, very simple explanation of benefits. Today we send probably 50
different types of mail, checks,

postcards, practically everything, but
But the key is to pick one small use case that they have a real problem around and
that you're going to go solve.

So that's what we did with Vosker and
he notes, and it's funny that he stayed, he's still one of our larger customers,
and

it all just came from like a three
sentence email to their CEO. >> Do you remember what
the headline of the email was?

>> It was like,
we can help you with your mail. >> We can help you with your mail,
that worked? >> It did work.

>> [LAUGH]
>> We've now learned a lot, that's probably what I do today. But at the time we knew that healthcare
sent a lot of mail, and we also did

that you've got mail, which got a pretty
good chuckle from folks in a day.

But really did, the core of the content
was in the first two lines which was like, we know companies have problems
to secure audible mail,

we built a technology
solution around doing this. Do you have 50 minutes to talk about it. That's pretty much what
the core content was,

but the key is to get
straight to the point. What are you going to solve? What's the problem and asking for
a little bit more time.

I never talk to CEO but he pounded me down
the chain but that got right eventually. >> So Tracy, I'm not an expert but
you're probably competing with

bigger traditional older incumbents
in some ways than Lob was, right? Do I have that wrong? What got you salable,
what got you really off the ground?

Beautiful software is great, but
we all want to build that, right? What made it salable? >> Sure, our first ten users,
I'm trained as a construction engineer, so

the first ten users were definitely
people we had worked with in the field. And it's easy to get our friends
to try out our software.

It's incredibly difficult to get
our friends to start paying for it. So-
>> That is a difference. >> Building something that they wanted and
that they needed that

added undeniable value to their day to day
was the moment they started paying us. >> Was the feedback from your
non paying friends useful?
Was it unhelpful? Was it dishelpful? >> So our first beta group which included

mostly people I'd worked with in
the field was about 30 people. 29 of them started paying us
as soon as the beta was over.

>> They did pay you. >> Hm-mm.
>> Got it. So were they bigger critics
than outside customers?

Sometimes it's hard to figure on how
to take advantage of friends as your own customers. >> Yeah,
yeah you're really testing my memory. >> [LAUGH]
>> So no, it was at that point in 2011,

2012 is about I want this to do more for
us. Can you build the XYZ?

>> Got it, and obviously the product
was FuturePoint at the time, right? What was the one piece
that was 10X better?
>> So blueprints are at the core. PlanGrid replaces physical blueprints. Fold-out maps, we don't have them anymore.

Actually with this group, you guys have probably never
purchased a fold-out map before. >> [LAUGH]
>> But we use Waze, we use Apple Maps,

we use Google Maps, and
with blueprints, it's the same analogy. These massive, incredibly dense
pieces of paper with information, and

they just don't render
quickly on PDF viewers. So it was just-
>> So what was the one line,

what was the pitch to make your
beautiful product salable? Was it [CROSSTALK]
>> I'm really glad. I was hoping you would ask
me what the tag line was.

>> What was the tag line? >> Our tag line, and
this is from my co-founder, Kenny. Our tag line was Plangrid
eliminates the ****.

Except that marketing has now changed it. So we're the productivity software for
contraction.

>> Got it, okay. We'll dig more on that, so boy,
where do we want to answer this questions.

So we start hosting applications,
right for others? >> Yeah.
>> What's their early history? Tell us what didn't work, or at least
didn't scale and that what did work.

>> Sure.
>> So you can sell the product. >> So the background here is, so nine years in, we started out as
a company called dotCloud, and now

we're a different company called Docker,
but there is a common thread, right? It's the same company, it's the same
team with the same mission but

we changed how we do it. And the first phase of dotCloud, well, let
me start with what the common thread is,

the common thread is we help
developers be more productive. We give them tools to create applications.

And then we help the businesses
behind those developers

solve their business problems
with the creation of software. And we're serving on these
trends of more people

creating software to do more things. So at the first phase,
we did that by hosting the applications.

So we said, just write the code, upload it
at to us, we'll take care of everything, we'll run it for you,
we'll manage it for you, all of it.

And, and then now, as Docker, we don't
do the hosting, we provide the tools.

You use the tools yourself, and
then you host the application and eventually as a business,
you need help with various aspect of

distributing your software at large scale. So in the first phase, we're very small,
we didn't have any sort of hype behind us.

We were just trying to convince
developers to use our stuff. Honestly we used our own community, where

programmers, we write software, and
we know a lot of other programmers and we just annoyed the hell out of
all of them to use our stuff.

We gave it to them for free, and then kind
of through the individual programmers,

eventually made our way to
the business behind the programmer. So the difference I think is that,
for us it's a two step process

that our users and our biggest advocates
are not the people paying for the product.

So, that means we have to
give a lot of stuff away for free before we even get the first
conversation with the actual buyer.

>> Yeah.
>> Yeah. >> So those first early years,

it's not even the same product
you have today remotely, right? How did you survive? Did you raise 50 million
in your seed round?

>> No.
>> How did you pull this off, right? Surviving's the hard part, right? >> Well, so
when you;'re a very small team,

you have kind of a limited window of time
where you could survive and earn a lot.

>> Yeah. It's hard usually for that to last
more than 24 months, isn't it? >> That's right. But, yeah, so
we joined Y Combinator in 2010 and

raised our first small round of funding
at the end of 2010, so within six months.

And we just went at it gradually. I mean,
it's nothing particularly unique there.

>> But you got into YC about
24 months after founding. >> Yeah, so
the frist part was really tough, it was bootstraps,
we did consulting, we did whatever.

>> Consulting was the hack.
>> It was the hack, whatever we had to do to pay the bills,
it was really tough. My advice would be consulting and
product building,

they're very useful but
you gotta get out of it really quickly because the consulting
takes all of your time.

You will never get off
the ground as a product company. There's too much distraction
in consulting, so eventually we just took a leap of faith.

>> Yes. >> And
landed on our feet in Y Combinator, so. >> Got it, and then one last question and
then I want to move on to the next topic.

But so what is now Docker
has gone through two and a half evolutions of business model,
right? And you've made Open Source work for
you, right?

What's the secret there? What's the learning? because we think it's hard
to monetize Open Source. >> Yeah, so
honestly I don't know how useful

my insights are here because really
the trick is to get really lucky. [LAUGH] And
the situation we're in now that

the Open Source technology that we
developed, Docker, is extremely popular. >> It is. >> We were in the right
place at the right time,

there's this whole trend on containers
which we kind of help start.

And now, just the demand for
it is honestly hard to describe. So, you

start having a completely different set of
problems once you are in that situation. So, honestly the problems we had
before that moment in 2013 when

we launched the Open Source Docker and
after, our world's apart. >> Yeah.
>> Now, honestly it's more, How do we
deliver on the incredible demands

fast enough before
the competitors do it instead? So there is no outbound in our case,
the question is too much inbound.

Which seems like nice a thing,
but it's actually- >> It's noise. >> It's noise and
also you drop a lot of it on the floor and

your competitors pick it up. >> Yeah, so, Tracy,
I want to come back to your fun story.

You hit up 30 of your friends from
construction and 29 became customers.

As you scale,
what do you do with customer feedback? How important is this? How much do you listen to?
How much of it is noise? How much do you let it guide your roadmap? What have you learned?

>> I don't know how you build
product without listening to your customers' feedback. We certainly take it incredibly seriously,
we've logged and

categorized every single piece of feedback
that our clients have given us since 2011.

It's incredibly easy
we've made that process. You just come on plangrid.com and
you're like, I want to give you feedback.

And then our support team will take it and
they'll ship it over to the product team. We'll look at it every quarter and
it does help us prioritize.

The big task here is making sure that
we're prioritizing the right stuff. Because sometimes our users will ask us,
can PlanGrid make up my breakfast and

dinner. And so,
when there's large general contractors and smaller subcontractors and building
owners asking us for the same button.

And telling us that if you just have this
thing, it's going to save me so much time, and there's enough domain
experience on the team.

When so many customers are asking for
the same thing, it's probably the right thing to build,
although tracking is obviously important.

But we typically look at it as,
how hard is this to build? How much resources do we have
to put into this versus,

how much value and
impact is it going to give our users? And if it's low level of effort and high
impact, we're going to prioritize that.

>> Absolutely. >> And that's really helped
us guide our product roadmap. >> And have you had any of
your bigger customers drag

your roadmap in a different way
than your smaller customers?

>> Yes, the larger customers, they want to
be treated like princes and princesses.

That they're running our entire business,
but they're incredible supportive of us.

It's nice that not any
single one customer has that big of a percentage of our revenue.

And so they just want to make sure
that we're listening to them, and that we're showing them what
the future of PlanGrid looks like,

and that we're constantly improving it. Because they're not only
buying PlanGrid today, but they're buying PlanGrid
six months from now.

It's a committment, right? It's a relationship. >> It's a long term commitment, right? And so, how many customers
total do you have at PlanGrid?

>> Tens of thousands. >> Tens of thousands? >> Mm-hm.
>> But the revenue distribution, it's probably several orders of magnitude
at your biggest customers, right?

>> Mm-hm, mm-hm.
>> When even if it's a couple percent of revenue or maybe in the early days, when they ask you to build something
that's kind of on your roadmap,

that's way out there,
because this is an issue we all face. Did you build it?

The B2C guys always say no, right? But when your big customer wants you to
build a 2019 feature, do you build it?

>> Again, if there's like,
a ton of the big customers asking us for the same thing,
it's easy to prioritize that.

But, we have never built a feature out for just one customer,
that doesn't make sense.

We're building software for the construction industry,
not XYZ Construction. >> Got it, yeah. Harry, Lob, is there a difference
between different sized customers?

>> Definitely a big difference
between our large and small customers. We spend a lot of time focusing
on the larger customers.

I think one thing you mentioned earlier,
right? Do our larger customers
impact our roadmap?

They certainly do, right? That said, I think it's also about
being transparent in the conversation,

from the first deal,
like what are you building? You're not just selling
one particular feature, one particular item,
it's a roadmap, right?

It's like you're investing at Lob, you're
going to be building infrastructure on it. We need to talk to that roadmap and
when larger customers are purchasing,

they're looking at what are we
building six months from now, trying to understand what that is. And for us, it's about finding
the balance between the type of

customers that we want. And listening to those customers a little
bit more that are more strategic.

So for us, we're selling something
that's very ubiquitous, right? Mail comes in many shapes,
formats, sizes, and

there's literally endless amounts
of combinations that we can do. And if we entertain every single request,

we'd end up going a million
directions all the time. So for us, we focus very
strategically on operational mail.

So mail that customers are compliant and required to send as
opposed to marketing mail.

That's not to say we don't do a lot
of marketing mail, we still do. But when we think about
roadmap conversations and

it comes to a trade off between A or B. We're always going to look
at the customer who one, we have a relationship with, right?

Two is the direction that we want
the company to move to begin with, and that's how we prioritize it. And sometimes,
that means saying no to customers.

And oftentimes we found
they're okay with that, so long as you're transparent
about what you're trying to do. >> Yeah, Solomon, let's talk,

you said in the beginning you guys were
five co-founders for two years, right? I think.

>> No, that. >> Roughly? I have that wrong? >> No, I think I heard five co-founders
>> Was it Tracy five?

>> Yeah.
>> We'll get into equity splits later. >> Okay.
>> At minute 51, until I learn how to add, okay?

But any related questions, so
I wanted to ask most of the panel this.

As you scale, let's talk about,
because this is always a great learning, a mishire, right? So as you get out your core team,
is there a core functional area or VP or

someone that you thought you needed or
got wrong in the early days? Anything you can learn from? What's the biggest hiring
mistake you've made?

>> I don't know about the biggest but we made a lot- >> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] >> We made a lot,

I don't know anyone who hasn't. >> Yes, but we can learn from this for
the next week, right?

>> Yeah, we can. >> This mistake a fewer times. >> Yeah, I mean, the biggest challenge is
once you've grown to full-fledged company,

then you grow outside
your zone of comfort. If you're in the technical and
product side,

then you'd have to hire business
people for the business side. You have to hire more technical and
product leadership.

And, it's things that at
some point you don't know. And you don't know what you don't know. And I remember as an engineer,
hiring non-engineers,

it was very difficult for me. Because I knew I needed help but
I didn't have the know-how to

distinguish the different kinds
of non-engineers that I needed.

It seems really silly to say that,
but to me marketing and sales, it was like the not coding thing.
And also, I moved to the US from France,

and Americans are extremely
good at selling themselves. >> You know I hear a lot
from European founders.

I hear that as a consistent theme. >> And so you're out here,
and you meet ten people. Wow, these are all rock stars [CROSSTALK]
>> Hire them right then and there.

>> Yeah, and you do. And then you realize,
okay, there's more to this. And the biggest problem is you're
when you hire the wrong person,

the state of mind is, it's a bad person. They're bad and my company's good and
now I hired the bad person.

But really what's happening is,
everyone's wasting their time. It's not the right
combination of people and

you're going to find out six months later
and it's going to be a terrible nuisance. So I don't really know if I've
learned anything how to avoid it.

But, every time we made a mistake, we've
tried to really invest the time to go back and find out why, what we did wrong.

So that we don't make the same
mistake twice, honestly. And I guess.

[CROSSTALK]
>> It's not the hired's fault, it's your fault, isn't it?

>> Yeah, exactly, that's exactly right. And my feeling is it's
the hardest at the beginning. But if you find,
once you have a core group of people,

like five key people in areas that you
don't really Understand and master, but you build a relationship
of trust with those people.

>> Yeah.
>> Then it gets easier because you trust them to hire more people. The really bad situation is if you
don't sort out that stuff early on.

Like you make a hire,
you feel like it might be a bad hire, but you don't deal with it right away. You allow it to Fester.

And then before you know it,
you're growing and that person has hired 20 more people. And now, you're in big trouble.

Because now, you gotta deal with
the mismatch, potentially, with 20 people. So my only advice would be, you're going to make mistakes, just deal
with them early and listen to you're gut.

If your gut says, maybe this is
the wrong thing, trust yourself, even if it it's not your
field of expertise.

I mean, I'm probably repeating
common sense here, but- >> We all make the same mistake.

Tracy, I want to hear your story too,
but let me flip it around. You've five co-founders,right? So you've got, you felt like you had
at least two of the bases covered in

the early days, at least in theory, right? What was one of these early hires you
made that was extremely impactful,

that moved the needle,
that helped increase the business? >> Our employee number one. >> Employee number one, who was that?

>> Cora Lorenz. Where early on there's nothing, and
you have to build something from nothing.

The more people that we can
get on the team to help realize our mission as a company
is incredibly important.

And I would say the same
about employee number two and employee number three and
employee number 300. >> Yeah. Was there a particular functional area or
someone that changed things for you?

They're all great. >> [LAUGH]
>> I mean we brought them on because we needed help, right? So it's hard to just pinpoint one person.

>> For sure,
well let me ask you a different question. You have five founders, when do you
bring on VP's or Directors or others to

take over the function layers, from that
what do you learn from that experience?

>> The point where we realize that as
being a founder especially doing it for the first time, so much of our jobs
is just learning on the spot and

trying to get the job done. As we've recruited more and more people,
the team, there comes a point where it's

like, wow, we have to become
really good at managing people. And this is all new for the founders.

I think we got pretty good at it, especially as just a frontline
engineering manager. But there comes to a point
where we're at 50 people,

150 people, and it's like Dunbar's
numbers, like complete chaos. Suddenly communication gets so
much harder.

And I think that's when we started
layering in executives who had done it before. Because now we have the experience of
people who aren't like the founders,

aren't learning on the job,
they've done it before, they've done it three times
before very successfully. And it just is much easier to
run the business that way.

>> Yeah, that's a good insight of when, we all want to hire the folks that
have done it before early, right?

Not all of us, but we get attracted
to the box on the resume, but maybe that Dunbar number is the right
time to think about it, right?

When did you benefit from folks that maybe
weren't as fluent in the product, but were fluent in the processes?

>> Yeah, if I could do it over,
I'd probably bring them on earlier, but at that point, it's just like you're
trying to recruit someone who's very,

very good at their jobs who are getting
paid tones of money where ever they're at. And it's hard to recruit them to your,
you know, little **** start up,

but you sell your butts off,
actually you never stop selling your butts off about your mission,
your vision as a company.

And so being able to deliver that
message of what you're trying to do and also showing the traction,
showing the growth.

When you see that graph,
everyone wants to be a part of it. >> They do, yeah. Was there a moment,
recruiting was always hard, but

was there a moment when it got easier? >> Practice. Practicing gets easier so I'd say maybe-
>> But from a brand perspective.

Get to the point? Did Sequoia or others, or Press or
you, I want to ask a related question,

but did it get,
in some ways easier when you became a more interesting startup
to a broader community?

>> Yeah, so we're a YC company,
we're also in the Sequoia portfolio. We flash that to our advantage.

>> Yeah.
[LAUGH] So good. So Harry,
any learnings on hiring mistakes or

great hire you made,
that moved the needle for you? >> Yeah so I can actually talk to one.

You mentioned earlier just like realizing
that, you need to hire good managers.

It was a big moment for
us in the past couple of years and that was actually one of
the early mistakes we made, which is one of our best IC's
thought he wanted to be a manager.

And we really wanted him
to managed a team too. He hadn't actually had
experience doing that before and

when we put him in that role,
he struggled. And that had some, that put us
through a tough six months, right?

And I think we learned a lesson early on,
it's like you want people who have already done it once before because even though
you may trust somebody and they're awesome
